sn42.1:1.2: “Fury” (caṇḍa) is a descriptive epithet used as a nickname. Such nicknames were a feature of the culture. Sometimes, texts invent a character as a vehicle for the teaching; such artifice may well have been intentional and received as such. By translating such names where appropriate, I aim to call attention to the way names are used to add a dimension of meaning. | Gāmaṇi is literally a “village headman”. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.4.4.18 establishes that the village headman ranks beneath the sūta (“equerry”, see SN 19.8:1.4 and note). However, it is used for a chief in general: in the next Sutta it is a “dancing master”, and in the one after that, a military rank.
